newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan dollar edges to lower close in range trade.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan dollar edges to lower close in range trade.

text.p: The Taiwan dollar ended slightly lower on Wednesday, continuing a slowly depreciating trend dating to mid-January, dealers said.

Some dealers said they saw U.S. dollar selling emerge when the Taiwan unit slipped to the T$27.90 level early in the day and said they suspected this was orchestrated by the central bank in a bid to smooth the Taiwan dollar's fall.
The local unit dipped to an intraday low of T$27.902 but rebounded a bit to end at T$27.891 against Tuesday's T$27.880 close. Turnover through dealers was an active US$258 million.
The Taiwan dollar has not closed lower since finishing at T$27.892 on May 28, 1996.
Dealers said demand for the U.S. dollar remained heavy in part because of the greenback's strength in overseas markets.
"Demand for the U.S. dollar is still quite active, but it seems the central bank had orchestrated a minor intervention to smooth the fall," said one dealer at a foreign bank.
A second dealer said: "The central bank has become very skillful in its intervention recently. We can't tell for sure if the central bank had intervened."
A narrow range of T$27.87-92 was seen for Thursday.
